title: Afterpay sticks to 'look over there' tactics
text:
One day, we hope to see an Afterpay ASX release that doesn't divert attention to a reassuring claim that was never in question.

Take Monday's "Response to Recent Media Commentary", addressing the straight-laced reporting of the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest in the sector. "Afterpay is not currently subject to an RBA inquiry or review process," it says in its second line.

Afterpay justifies high fees by referrals of customers to merchants over its platform.

Well, thank God for that. But no one ever said it was.

Everyone did ⁠report on the Reserve Bank's stated intention to review the sector's use of "no surcharge" rules next year, flagged (somewhat uncannily) a mere day after a critical UBS analyst report suggested this margin-preserving business tactic could be an issue.

The tenor of Afterpay's response reminds us of the time it flagged AUSTRAC's interest in its compliance ... on page 16 of a largely laudatory release. Or later, when it said an AUSTRAC-ordered review – commissioned to look at Afterpay's Know Your Customer compliance – hadn't identified any instances of money-laundering. Well of course it hadn't: it wasn't looking for any!

But back to Monday's release, which, further down, stressed Afterpay's good relationships with merchants and customers who, presumably, would figure its 4 per cent fee worth it. It's not a bad argument. Beats us why it chose to lead on another ...
